I loved this question - a bit more sophisticated than the usual "what will the price of X be in 3 months time?".  A shame that it ended so quickly! Main learning point for me was the improvement in how to model a "race to a target" between multiple players, where the players can move backwards too (price fall) not just relentlessly forwards: I should compare ratios of odds, rather than ratios of probabilities.  It's still a very rough model (but hey, didn't "Thinking Fast and Slow" say simple models are often the best?), but eyeballing the outputs, the fit seems MUCH better now. I hope we get a similar question in the near future!

OK, a bit of witchcraft making this forecast.  Be interesting to see how this pans out. ASSUMPTIONS
a)  These four companies, on average, have their price fluctuate identically to fluctuations in the NASDAQ.
b)  Current share prices represent the shared wisdom about not just the current value of these companies, but value of these companies in the next few months.  Future share prices are likely to be a random walk from the current price, with an mean result similar to prior movements in the NASDAQ.
c)  The price movements of these four companies are more likely to be independent than perfectly correlated.**
d)  The share price of Alphabet fluctuates significantly more wildly than the the share price of the other 3 companies. [** The maths for a scenario other than one of these 2 extremes is beyond me.  So either I commit to saying, "Apple is in front now, so Apple will always be in front", or else I assume that the random walk that each company's valuation takes is unrelated to the walk taken by the other companies, constrained only be the general tendency to walk in a way that can be modelled by past NASDAQ movements.  Given the past price movements, I think the latter is closer to the truth than the former ... as the former is demonstrably incorrect.] STEP ONE
Take data of NASDAQ closing price on a daily basis over the last 10 years. STEP TWO
Given today's prices, calculate what % growth each company needs to hit the target.
*  For Apple, a valuation increase of +6.3% is required.
*  For Alphabet, a valuation increase of +20.9% is required. STEP THREE
Given there are 115 weekdays between now and the resolution point of the question, how often in the last 10 years has the NASDAQ closing price on a given day varied upwards (compared to the closing price 115 market days prior) by more than the percentage required top "hit the target"?
*  For Apple, the NASDAQ has increased in value by +6.3% or more 1449 times out of the last 2404, or 60.3% of the time.
*  For Alphabet, the NASDAQ has increased in value by +20.9% or more 164 times out of the last 2404, or 6.8% of the time. This simulates the probability that the given company's valuation will exceed 1 terabuck (T$) at close of market on 31 December. STEP FOUR
If a company's probability of being valued at T$1+ at the close of the year = (n), then the probability of being valued at at T$1+ at the close of ANY day before then must be significantly greater than (n). This is pure guess work, but let:
p(closing price of T$1- on EVERY day before 1Jan) = [p(closing price of T$1- on 31Dec)]^2 ... but use ^3 for Alphabet because of it's more highly fluctuating price - it is more likely than the others to have gone above target then fallen back below. *  For Apple, failing to hit target on 31Dec 39.7% of the time, means failing to hit target at any point before then 15.8% of the time.  (0.397^2)
*  For Alphabet, failing to hit target on 31Dec 93.2% of the time, means failing to hit target at any point before then 81.0% of the time.  (0.932^3). STEP FIVE
Assuming the probabilities of EACH company failing to hit target at any point before 1Jan are independent, the probability of ALL companies failing to hit target can be determined by multiplying the individual probabilities. * This gives a 6.5% chance that NO company will hit target, and a 93.5% chance that AT LEAST ONE company will hit target before 1 January. STEP SIX
Assuming ANY company hits target, the odds of each company hitting target first is proportional to the probability that that company will hit target at ANY point before the end of year (as determined in STEP FOUR).  Converting those odds back into percentages, we get:
*  Apple are 53.9% likely to win the race, assuming the race is won.
*  Alphabet are 12.2% likely to win the race, assuming the race is won. STEP SEVEN
Multiple the probabilities at STEP SIX by 0.935 (as determined in STEP FIVE) to get the individual companies' chances of hitting target AND beating all the others to the target. **********************************

I don't have strong conviction whether the market will rise or fall/remain flat the rest of the year from here. If it does not rise, I see virtually no chance of any company crossing the highly psychological $1 trillion barrier. If it does rise, Amazon and Apple are best positioned to get there given proximity.  Apple has a lot  ($150+ Billion)of overseas money committed to buybacks given changes in tax policy that allow them to bring overseas money back at a rate they are willing to pay.  But while buy backs are good for share price, the reduction of outstanding shares actually reduce market cap. Thus it is mainly the anticipation of buybacks, resulting in higher stock price, that could push them over the $1 Trillion threshold this year. Amazon's continued growth in revenue, overall market share of U.S online spending, along with AWS and progress towards profitability could also cause their share price to climb enough to reach $1 trillion this year, but I find it somewhat unlikely they would pass Apple in market capitalization, hence my weighting of Apple above Amazon
